title: How to write a cover letter for a CV - Quora

response.answer_text: You already have awesome answers for how to write a cover letter for your resume. I will just state some rules you must never forget: Never write your cover letter before your resume[1]. Cover letters, by their very nature, must address the issues your resume raises.Ensure that your cover letter matches your resume in style and formatWrite facts and not general statements “I am a result-oriented bla bla bla” is bull shit. Instead, say something like “I am a civil engineer with X years working experience and I have handled teams across X countries…”Your cover letter is an assessor, it should not duplicate your resume.Carefully write your cover letter to answer any key question your resume might raise such as an unemployment gap, reason for X number of job changes in 3 years.Pay close attention to incorporating keywords relevant to the industry you are applying to.Stick to making one point per paragraph.Show insights in your cover letter.End your cover letter humbly Never say “If you have some time, I will like to discuss my candidacy with you” They don’t have ‘SOME TIME” and who says they want to talk to you??? Instead say something like “If the firm finds me a fit based on my paper profile and would like to further discuss my candidacy, I would make myself available.”I hope this helps. Footnotes[1] Consulting Resume: How to Edit a Resume That Gets You an Interview - Firmsconsulting l Strategy Skills & Case Interviews

I am sorry I’m not going to answer your question in a straight forward way but rather share a tip that I used many times in order to create the best resumé/ cover letter I could. If you google [Any large US college] + “career resource” or “career services”, you will be redirected to the Career Services of the school which often has free PDF to download with resumé/ cover letter tips, examples, DOs and DON’Ts as well as tools (list of action verbs for resumés)… Here is a quick example for Harvard here : LMGTFY Once you have those, here a few tips from my experience Read the theory for the cover letterThe document will explain the purpose of a CL, what employers are look for etc. Don’t worry if different material don’t say the same thing, just pick whatever makes the most sense for youRead example of cover letters, if possible chose one which is close to your field of work, but other letters are also interestingAvoid copying and pasting CL found in the material, but use snippet or ideasHope it helps and that you are successful in your applications. PS: if I remember correctly when I was applying I used Harvard, Yale and Princeton. PS2: if you are in a rush and don’t want to google the stuff yourself here is a quick guide from Harvard : https://ocs.fas.harvard.edu/files/ocs/files/hes-resume-cover-letter-guide.pdf
